parts:
Give me a high-level summary of what the Singapore Government has said. Examine the possible triggers for the latest statements on Gaza by the government, and fact check the most important claims made.

---

Singapore says denial of aid in Gaza violates international humanitarian law
"The prolonged suffering of innocent civilians in Gaza arising from the excessive Israeli military reaction to the terror attacks of Hamas since Oct 7, 2023, is unconscionable," said Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 

Singapore says denial of aid in Gaza violates international humanitarian law
Palestinians wait to receive food from a charity kitchen in Gaza City, on Jul 24, 2025. (Photo: REUTERS/Khamis Al-Rifi)


Listen
3 min
Darcel Al Anthony
24 Jul 2025 08:35PM
(Updated: 24 Jul 2025 09:56PM)
Bookmark
WhatsApp
Telegram
Facebook
Twitter
Email
LinkedIn
Read a summary of this article on FAST.
FAST
SINGAPORE: Singapore on Thursday (Jul 24) issued its strongest comments yet on the situation in Gaza, saying that mass starvation caused by the denial of aid constitutes a violation of international humanitarian law.

In remarks released on Thursday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) described the impact of Israel’s ongoing military response as “unconscionable” and called for an immediate ceasefire.

"The prolonged suffering of innocent civilians in Gaza arising from the excessive Israeli military reaction to the terror attacks of Hamas since Oct 7, 2023, is unconscionable. Israel must comply with its international humanitarian obligations," said an MFA spokesperson.

ADVERTISEMENT

"The denial of humanitarian aid has caused mass starvation and a dire lack of essential medical services. The reports of people being shot whilst desperately trying to access food are shocking," said the spokesperson.

"This is a violation of international humanitarian law."

All civilians must be protected, especially those accessing humanitarian supplies, the spokesperson added.

"Permanent forced displacement is a further violation of international humanitarian law."

Singapore called on the Israeli government to immediately lift all restrictions on the delivery of humanitarian assistance and to allow the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) to resume its operations.

ADVERTISEMENT

Related:

More than 100 aid, rights groups call for action as hunger spreads in Gaza

28 nations, including Japan, condemn Israel over 'inhumane killing' of Gaza civilians
On Wednesday, World Health Organization (WHO) chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said that Gaza is facing a "man-made" mass starvation, pointing to the ongoing Israeli blockade and restrictions on humanitarian aid deliveries.

Israel has justified the restrictions as necessary to prevent aid from being diverted to militants, and maintains it has facilitated the delivery of adequate food supplies.

According to Gaza’s health ministry, more than 100 people have died from starvation since the conflict began.

ADVERTISEMENT

The WHO added that at least 21 children have died from malnutrition this year, though it cautioned that the actual toll is likely much higher.

Related:

Commentary: Why Singapore PM Wong's recent comments on Israel actions in Gaza are significant
Thursday's remarks mark the first time Singapore has explicitly described the situation in Gaza as a violation of international humanitarian law.

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said in May that by restricting aid into Gaza, Israel's actions may be a "likely breach of international humanitarian law". 

"Israel's response has gone too far and its actions have caused terrible humanitarian disaster; and the restrictions imposed on the delivery of humanitarian supplies are completely unacceptable," said Mr Wong on May 30.

ADVERTISEMENT

In Thursday's remarks, Singapore urged Hamas to release all remaining hostages immediately and unconditionally.

It also reiterated its longstanding call for a two-state solution, saying that it was the "only viable path" for both Israelis and Palestinians to live side by side "with peace, security, and dignity".

"The current trajectory of events will only make this eventual goal even more difficult to achieve, and condemn both Israelis and Palestinians to an endless cycle of mutual hatred and violence," said the MFA spokesperson.

entries.title: 'Comply:' PM's stern demand to Israel
entries.snippet: In his strongest remarks yet concerning the Gaza conflict, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese demanded Israel comply with international law and end its blockade that has worsened a growing humanitarian catastrophe. He condemned Israel's restrictions on aid and the killing of civilians, asserting that such actions are indefensible. Albanese called for allowing UN and NGO workers access and denounced any efforts to forcibly displace Palestinians. His statement came after Australia joined 26 other countries in criticizing Israel’s limited aid and civilian casualties, pledging to support a ceasefire and a peaceful resolution. Conditions in Gaza are dire, with the UN reporting widespread malnutrition among children and over 6,000 aid trucks being blocked. WHO Director Tedros Adhanom described the crisis as "man-made mass starvation," with the Gaza health ministry reporting 111 starvation deaths. The U.S. has also exited ceasefire talks, blaming Hamas. Albanese reaffirmed Australia's commitment to a two-state solution and condemned Hamas’s violence while supporting Israel's right to exist. Domestically, the conflict has stirred protests, with 17 people removed from Parliament House and Greens Senator Mehreen Faruqi sanctioned for publicly challenging the PM on Gaza policy during a parliamentary address.

The conflict remains deadlocked as Hamas demands a full Israeli withdrawal and Israel insists Hamas must disarm. The humanitarian crisis in Gaza continues to worsen with over 59,000 Palestinians killed and famine conditions escalating, causing an alarming rise in child malnutrition and deaths. Aid access is severely restricted, and even journalists face starvation. France has announced recognition of a Palestinian state, drawing condemnation from Israel and the U.S., while being welcomed by the Palestinian Authority. Meanwhile, ceasefire negotiations show mixed signals—some officials see Hamas' latest proposal as "workable," but hardline Israeli and U.S. responses persist. International pressure mounts on Israel to allow humanitarian aid and end the war. Military-related incidents, attacks in the West Bank, and settler violence continue to inflame tensions. Despite worsening conditions, a proposed 60-day ceasefire deal involving phased hostage releases and aid increases remains under discussion.

entries.title: Israel and US pull out of Gaza ceasefire talks with 'selfish' Hamas
entries.snippet:
Ceasefire negotiations in Gaza have collapsed after the United States and Israel withdrew from talks in Qatar, citing Hamas's unwillingness to act in good faith. U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff and Israeli representatives ended discussions over a truce intended to pave the way for hostage-prisoner exchanges and address humanitarian aid distribution. The central disagreements involved the sustained presence of Israeli forces in Gaza and terms for a permanent ceasefire.

As negotiations break down, Gaza’s two million inhabitants face worsening humanitarian conditions. Aid agencies, including the UN’s World Food Programme and WHO, warn of mass starvation, rising malnutrition among children, and inadequate access to food and water due to Israeli blockades and dangers faced by aid workers. The UN reports over 1,000 Palestinians have died while queuing for aid over two months, and 30,000 children are acutely malnourished.

The Israeli government blames UN agencies for failing to distribute aid, while humanitarian groups argue that Israeli restrictions and security threats are the main obstacles. Hamas has called for global protests to end the siege and famine. Despite earlier hope for progress following Witkoff’s travel for talks, the impasse continues amid mounting human suffering in the Gaza Strip.

entries.title: New MPs deliver first speeches - as it happened
entries.snippet:
The 48th Australian Parliament officially opened on July 22, 2025, with the swearing-in of new members, ceremonial proceedings, and the first speeches from newly elected MPs, prominently Labor’s Ali France and Sarah Witty. France unseated Peter Dutton in Dickson, and Witty defeated Adam Bandt in Melbourne. Both shared personal stories that underscored their values and political commitments—France drew on her recovery from a serious accident and Witty on her experience as a foster carer and advocate.

Sue Lines was re-elected as Senate President and Milton Dick returned as Speaker of the House. Despite Pauline Hanson surprisingly nominating David Pocock for the Senate role, he declined.

A joint statement signed by Australia and 24 other countries condemned Israeli actions in Gaza, sparking political debate. Greens senator Mehreen Faruqi staged a protest in Parliament demanding sanctions against Israel, drawing criticism from Ministers and fellow MPs.

The Senate is set to initiate an inquiry into the environmental crisis caused by an algal bloom in South Australia. Meanwhile, major legislation backed by both Labor and the Coalition—including a 20% student debt reduction and enhanced childcare safety regulation—is expected to pass with little resistance. Protests and vigils also took place outside Parliament highlighting humanitarian concerns in Gaza.

entries.title: Dozens of kids and adults in Gaza have starved to death in July as hunger surges
entries.snippet:
In July 2025, Gaza has experienced a severe hunger crisis resulting in the deaths of at least 48 people, including 28 adults and 20 children, due to acute malnutrition. The crisis reached a tipping point as Israel’s blockade, in place since March, led to critical shortages of food and medical supplies. Patient's Friends Hospital in Gaza is overwhelmed, treating hundreds of malnourished children daily with minimal resources. Key nutrients and treatments, such as potassium supplements, have largely run out, contributing to multiple child fatalities. The U.N. reports similarly bleak data, estimating nearly 100,000 women and children urgently need treatment for malnutrition.

Adults with preexisting conditions such as diabetes and heart disease, now compounded by starvation, are also dying. Israel began easing the blockade in late May, allowing a limited number of aid trucks to enter, far below necessary levels. Efforts to distribute aid have been hindered by chaos and shortages. Israel attributes the crisis to Hamas’s interference, while the U.N. emphasizes Israel’s role in restricting aid. Aid organizations stress that a substantial, consistent inflow of supplies is essential to prevent further deaths and address the growing humanitarian emergency.

parts:
### 1  |  What the Singapore Government actually said  
Singapore’s **Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA)** issued a press statement on 24 July 2025 that markedly sharpened earlier criticism of Israel’s conduct in Gaza:  

* **Humanitarian‑law breach.** MFA called the “prolonged suffering” of civilians “unconscionable” and said that **mass starvation caused by the denial of aid, together with shootings at people seeking food, “is a violation of international humanitarian law.”**citeturn1view0  
* **Demands on Israel.** Singapore urged Israel to **lift all restrictions on aid, allow UNRWA to resume operations**, and protect all civilians, “especially those accessing humanitarian supplies.”citeturn1view0  
* **Demands on Hamas.** It simultaneously pressed Hamas to **release all hostages immediately and unconditionally**.citeturn1view0  
* **Forced displacement.** MFA warned that any *permanent* removal of Palestinians would also break international law.citeturn1view0  
* **Political end‑state.** The statement reaffirmed Singapore’s long‑standing support for a **negotiated two‑state solution**.citeturn1view0  

This is the strongest language Singapore has used since Prime Minister **Lawrence Wong’s 30 May 2025 remark** that Israel’s aid restrictions were “likely” already breaching international humanitarian law.citeturn8search1  

---

### 2  |  Likely triggers for the tougher wording  

| Trigger | Evidence | Why it matters for Singapore’s timing |
|---------|----------|---------------------------------------|
| **WHO’s “man‑made mass starvation” alert (23 Jul)** | WHO Director‑General Tedros called the crisis “man‑made mass starvation” the day before the MFA statement.citeturn4view0 | Made it harder for neutral states to remain silent; provided a fresh, authoritative public‐health basis for speaking out. |
| **Joint statement by 28 mostly Western and Asian states (21 Jul)** condemning Israel’s “drip‑feeding” of aid | The text highlights aid denial and warns against forced displacement.citeturn7search1 | Singapore was not a signatory, but the peer pressure from close partners (e.g., Japan, Australia) raised diplomatic costs of staying on the sidelines. |
| **Domestic signals**: Acting Minister‑in‑charge of Muslim Affairs Faishal Ibrahim publicly endorsed the 28‑nation call on 23 Jul.citeturn3view0 | Signalled rising domestic expectation—especially from Singapore’s sizable Muslim minority—for a clearer moral stance. |
| **Worsening battlefield indicators** (starvation deaths, shootings at aid lines, stalled cease‑fire talks) | UN‑OCHA recorded *634* Palestinians killed near food sites between 27 May and 10 Jul.citeturn6search5  Cease‑fire talks collapsed the same week.citeturn6news8 | Made MFA’s earlier, more cautious language (“may be a likely breach”) look dated; necessitated an update. |

---

### 3  |  Fact‑checking the MFA’s key claims  

| MFA claim | Factual status | Evidence & context |
|-----------|----------------|--------------------|
| **“Denial of humanitarian aid has caused mass starvation.”** | **Supported.** | WHO describes the situation as “man‑made mass starvation”.citeturn4view0  Gaza’s health authority reports **111 starvation deaths**, 80 of them children.citeturn4view0  UN screening shows **9 % of <5‑year‑olds** now severely malnourished.citeturn5view0 |
| **“People being shot whilst desperately trying to access food.”** | **Supported.** | UN‑OHCHR documents **> 634 fatalities** near “militarised food‑distribution sites” in six weeks.citeturn6search5  Independent reporting records individual incidents with dozens of deaths (e.g., Khan Younis, 17 Jun).citeturn6search4 |
| **“Permanent forced displacement is a violation of IHL.”** | **Legally accurate.** | The same wording appears in the 28‑nation joint statement and multiple UNSC briefings.citeturn7search0 |
| **Israel must lift restrictions.** | **Contentious but broadly validated by neutral observers.** | Israel’s COGAT claims aid “beyond the standards of international law” with **1 000 truck‑loads waiting for UN pickup**.citeturn5view0  Yet pre‑war norms were **≈500 trucks/day** versus ≈28 trucks now reaching civilians.citeturn4view0  Aid agencies and WHO insist the shortfall is the main driver of famine conditions. |
| **“Mass starvation violates international humanitarian law.”** | **Correct.** | Starvation of civilians as a method of warfare is prohibited under Article 54 of Additional Protocol I to the Geneva Conventions and customary IHL Rule 53 (ICRC). |

---

### 4  |  Overall assessment  

* **Consistency** – The 24 July statement does not break with Singapore’s traditionally cautious, law‑based stance. It **escalates** the language in response to clear external triggers (WHO alert, multilateral pressure) and grim new data.  
* **Balance** – MFA still condemns Hamas hostage‑taking and re‑asserts Israel’s right to security, but positions the aid blockade and shootings as indefensible under IHL.  
* **Credibility of claims** – Independent UN bodies, WHO data and on‑the‑ground reporting **corroborate** Singapore’s main allegations. Israel’s counter‑narrative (ample aid, UN distribution failures) is noted but not substantiated by neutral metrics on actual deliveries versus need.

In short, Singapore’s latest remarks reflect mounting international evidence that Gaza’s humanitarian catastrophe is *both* avoidable and unlawful, and they align the Republic with an emerging multilateral consensus calling for an immediate cease‑fire and unrestricted aid access.

entries.title: More than 30 killed by gunfire near U.S. aid site in Gaza
entries.snippet: More than 30 Palestinians were killed and at least 170 wounded, mostly by gunfire, near a U.S.-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) aid distribution site in southern Gaza on Sunday. Witnesses and medical officials reported that gunfire originated from nearby Israeli military positions, but the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) denied firing at civilians, citing an internal inquiry. The GHF and the IDF claim incidents occurred outside their operational zones. Doctors Without Borders described the event as a "massacre," with victims suffering serious gunshot wounds. The humanitarian crisis in Gaza has deepened since Israel blocked most aid deliveries in early March, pushing many regions toward famine. The GHF, criticized for its limited and risky distribution approach, requires civilians to travel long distances, often exposing them to danger. Humanitarian leaders, including the UN’s World Food Program, have called for opening crossings and improving aid access. This latest incident reflects recurring violence near aid centers since the GHF began operations, with a reported 49 fatalities over the past week. Medical facilities are overwhelmed and understocked, with staff donating blood to meet urgent needs. The international community continues to urge for safer, more effective humanitarian response mechanisms.

entries.title: 31 Palestinians are killed heading to a Gaza aid site, witnesses say. Israel denies responsibility
entries.snippet: At least 31 Palestinians were killed and over 170 wounded in Rafah, Gaza on Sunday as crowds headed to receive food aid near a site operated by an Israeli-backed foundation. Witnesses claimed Israeli forces opened fire before dawn, while the Israeli military denied targeting civilians, stating only warning shots were fired at suspects. Drone footage released by Israel purportedly shows armed men firing at civilians, though it remains unverified. The International Committee of the Red Cross reported their Rafah hospital saw its highest number of weapon-related casualties since opening. U.N. officials called the aid distribution system a "death trap," criticizing it for violating humanitarian principles and causing forced displacement. Despite the foundation’s claim of peaceful aid delivery, several witnesses and health officials reported gunfire and chaos. Additional Israeli shelling in Khan Younis killed three more people. Meanwhile, the U.N. and aid agencies struggle to distribute aid amid Israeli restrictions and security concerns. The war, sparked in October 2023 after a Hamas-led attack, has resulted in over 54,000 deaths in Gaza, with widespread destruction and critical humanitarian needs. Ceasefire talks remain stalled as diplomatic efforts continue.

entries.title: Gunmen shoot at Gazans getting food at aid center, footage released by Israel shows
entries.snippet: Drone footage released by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) shows masked gunmen in Gaza allegedly shooting and throwing stones at civilians collecting humanitarian aid in Khan Younis. The IDF claims the perpetrators are preventing food distribution in Gaza, attributing the attack to Hamas. This video emerged following conflicting reports about a deadly incident in Rafah, where over 30 Palestinians were reportedly killed and nearly 170 injured near another aid distribution site. While the Hamas-controlled Gaza Health Ministry confirmed casualties, the US-based Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) reported no injuries or deaths at the same location. An Israeli soldier stated that IDF forces fired near, but not at, the crowd. The IDF insists its troops did not target civilians and accused Hamas of spreading misinformation. The IDF stated it is cooperating with GHF and international organizations to ensure aid delivery to civilians and not Hamas. Witness accounts claimed Israeli tanks approached as crowds gathered, prompting the IDF to reiterate its commitment to thoroughly investigate each allegation and maintain professionalism in its military conduct.

Witnesses and medical officials reported that gunfire originated from nearby Israeli military positions, but the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) denied firing at civilians, citing an internal inquiry. The GHF and the IDF claim incidents occurred outside their operational zones. Doctors Without Borders described the event as a "massacre," with victims suffering serious gunshot wounds. The humanitarian crisis in Gaza has deepened since Israel blocked most aid deliveries in early March, pushing many regions toward famine. The GHF, criticized for its limited and risky distribution approach, requires civilians to travel long distances, often exposing them to danger. Humanitarian leaders, including the UN’s World Food Program, have called for opening crossings and improving aid access. This latest incident reflects recurring violence near aid centers since the GHF began operations, with a reported 49 fatalities over the past week. Medical facilities are overwhelmed and understocked, with staff donating blood to meet urgent needs. The international community continues to urge for safer, more effective humanitarian response mechanisms.

entries.title: More Than 100 Dead From Hunger in Gaza, Including Dozens of Children
entries.snippet:
Since the onset of the war between Israel and Hamas, at least 113 individuals in Gaza—including 81 children—have died due to famine and malnutrition, according to Gaza's Health Ministry. Over 28,000 malnutrition cases have been reported, with more than 5,000 in July alone. The World Health Organization has labeled the crisis a "man-made" famine caused by blockade-related disruptions. All treatment facilities for acute malnutrition are currently overwhelmed and running out of supplies.

While more than 100 aid organizations have demanded immediate humanitarian access, they cite logistical obstructions and Israeli siege policies as core contributors to the crisis. Israel denies causing famine, blaming Hamas for aid disruptions. The new Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) aid distribution plan has drawn sharp criticism for forcing civilians to cross dangerous zones for aid.

Since the GHF program began in May, over 1,000 Palestinians have died while seeking food, many near aid centers. Groups including the Red Cross report thousands of injuries linked to aid efforts. The crisis is worsening due to ongoing violence and infrastructure collapse, with journalists now also facing acute hunger. Over 59,000 Palestinians have died since the war began, according to Gaza's Health Ministry.

entries.title: The Latest: US cuts short Gaza ceasefire talks, blaming Hamas
entries.snippet: The U.S. is withdrawing its negotiating team from Gaza ceasefire talks in Qatar, citing Hamas's lack of commitment to reaching a resolution. The conflict remains deadlocked as Hamas demands a full Israeli withdrawal and Israel insists Hamas must disarm. The humanitarian crisis in Gaza continues to worsen with over 59,000 Palestinians killed and famine conditions escalating, causing an alarming rise in child malnutrition and deaths. Aid access is severely restricted, and even journalists face starvation. France has announced recognition of a Palestinian state, drawing condemnation from Israel and the U.S., while being welcomed by the Palestinian Authority. Meanwhile, ceasefire negotiations show mixed signals—some officials see Hamas' latest proposal as "workable," but hardline Israeli and U.S. responses persist. International pressure mounts on Israel to allow humanitarian aid and end the war. Military-related incidents, attacks in the West Bank, and settler violence continue to inflame tensions. Despite worsening conditions, a proposed 60-day ceasefire deal involving phased hostage releases and aid increases remains under discussion.

entries.title: UN body says Israeli forces have killed over 1,000 aid-seekers in Gaza since May, as hunger worsens
entries.snippet:
Since May 2025, over 1,000 Palestinians in Gaza have been killed by Israeli forces while seeking food aid, primarily near sites managed by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), an Israeli-backed American contractor, according to the U.N. human rights office. The situation is deteriorating amid an ongoing Israeli offensive and restrictions on humanitarian access, creating famine-like conditions for over 2 million residents. The Gaza Health Ministry reports 101 starvation-related deaths—80 children since the war began and 21 adults since Sunday.

U.N. agencies and aid groups, including MedGlobal, confirm that the population is facing catastrophic hunger, with nearly 100,000 women and children experiencing severe malnutrition. The chaos surrounding limited food distribution has led to violence, stampedes, and deadly Israeli strikes near aid convoys and shelters. A strike on the Shati refugee camp killed at least 12 people, including women and children, while another on aid seekers killed eight.

Despite international condemnation from 28 Western-aligned nations, including the UK and France, Israel and the U.S. continue to blame Hamas for the humanitarian crisis. The war, triggered by Hamas' October 7, 2023 attack, has killed over 59,000 Palestinians, with more than half reported as women and children.

entries.title: Three people reported killed and dozens wounded near aid site in Gaza, medics say
entries.snippet: At least three Palestinians were killed and dozens wounded near an aid distribution site in Rafah, Gaza, reportedly due to Israeli military fire, according to local health authorities. The Israeli military acknowledged the incident occurred approximately 1 km from the U.S.-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) site and stated warning shots were fired to deter approaching individuals. The GHF, endorsed by Israel, denied any casualties at its facility, claiming reports of fatalities as false. The incident follows Sunday’s deadly episode near the same GHF site, where at least 31 people were reportedly killed, drawing condemnation from UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres who urged an independent investigation. As Israel's military campaign in Gaza intensifies, including expanded ground operations and airstrikes that killed 51 in 24 hours, the humanitarian crisis deepens. The UN warns of possible famine among Gaza's 2 million residents, exacerbated by an 11-week blockade. The GHF claims to have distributed nearly 6 million meals but faces criticism for bypassing traditional aid channels. Meanwhile, ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas continue under Arab and U.S. mediation amidst mutual blame. Israel's offensive began after the October 2023 Hamas attack, having since killed over 54,000 Palestinians and reduced much of Gaza to ruins.

entries.title: Weaponisation of food in Gaza constitutes war crime, UN rights office says
entries.snippet: The United Nations human rights office has condemned the "weaponisation" of food aid in Gaza, calling it a potential war crime. This statement marks the UN’s strongest criticism yet of the Israeli-supported Gaza Humanitarian Foundation’s new aid distribution system. According to Thameen Al-Kheetan, a spokesperson for the UN human rights office, more than 410 individuals have been killed by Israeli military fire while attempting to access food distribution points since late May. These figures, sourced from Palestinian health authorities and NGOs, are still under verification. Al-Kheetan described the situation as forcing civilians into an inhumane choice between starvation and risking death, labeling the mechanism as a "militarised humanitarian assistance" system. He emphasized that restricting or weaponizing access to essential food and services is a war crime and may also constitute other international criminal offenses. When asked directly if Israel is guilty of such crimes, he indicated that such determinations must be made by a court of law. Israel denies the allegations and maintains that Hamas is responsible for endangering civilians by operating within their vicinity, a charge Hamas has denied.

entries.title: Overcrowding forces halt to Gaza aid distribution, Eid holiday marked by violence
entries.snippet:
Aid distribution in Gaza was suspended on June 6, 2025, due to unsafe overcrowding, as reported by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), which is supported by the U.S. and Israel. The halt comes amidst severe food shortages and ongoing Israeli military operations targeting Hamas across the Gaza Strip. On the same day, 16 Palestinians were reportedly killed in Israeli airstrikes, while four Israeli soldiers died in an explosion in Khan Younis. Despite initially stating that food had been distributed peacefully, GHF later closed its gates citing security concerns.

The distribution process, launched in late May, has faced criticism for being chaotic and poorly organized, with only two out of three promised distribution sites operational. Eid al-Adha was marked under grim conditions with Palestinians conducting prayers amid ruins and continuing bombings. Israel’s actions follow the collapse of a ceasefire in March, with its military campaign triggered by a Hamas-led attack in October 2023. To date, over 54,000 Palestinians have been killed in the conflict, according to Gaza’s health authorities, while 1,200 Israelis died in the initial Hamas assault. The United Nations has warned of widespread famine risks, with malnutrition among children tripling during Israel’s 11-week blockade.

entries.title: UN chief slams US-backed Gaza aid operation: 'It is killing people'
entries.snippet:
UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has strongly criticized a U.S.-backed aid operation in Gaza, denouncing it as "inherently unsafe" and responsible for causing civilian deaths. Guterres condemned the controversial Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), supported by the U.S. and Israel, citing concerns over its militarized aid distribution model, forced displacement, and lack of neutrality. Despite the partial lifting of an 11-week Israeli blockade in May, which allowed limited UN aid delivery, over 400 Palestinians have reportedly died while attempting to access aid, many at or near GHF sites.

Israel has rejected the UN's criticism, claiming its military does not target civilians and accusing the UN of aligning with Hamas to obstruct GHF efforts. GHF countered the UN’s allegations, asserting no deaths occurred near its distribution points and emphasized its success in delivering over 48 million meals using private U.S. security and logistics firms. The U.S. recently authorized $30 million in funding for the GHF and urged global support. Guterres also highlighted the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Gaza, as UN aid workers face starvation, and reiterated calls for an immediate ceasefire, emphasizing that seeking food should not cost lives.

parts:
## 1 | What the allegation is

Since late May 2025 the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) and the U.S./Israeli‑backed **Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF)** have claimed that *Hamas gunmen* are opening fire on Palestinians at food‑distribution points to sow chaos and discredit GHF.  
* **Flagship example – 1 June 2025 (Khan Younis):** the IDF released 30‑second quad‑copter footage that shows three masked shooters firing AK‑style rifles and throwing rocks at a crowd heading toward a GHF hub. The army captioned it “Hamas does everything it can to prevent the success of the food distribution in Gaza.”citeturn7view0  
* **Bus ambush – 11 June 2025:** GHF said a bus carrying its workers was raked with gunfire en route to a distribution site, killing eight; the foundation blamed Hamas in a feud with a rival clan.citeturn10view0

No other specific cases have been publicly documented by Israel, GHF or major newswires.

---

## 2 | What independent evidence exists

| Aspect | Findings | Sources & comments |
|--------|----------|--------------------|
| **Authenticity of the 1 June video** | *Unverified.*  Independent outlets carried the clip exactly as supplied by the IDF; no third‑party forensic group (e.g., Bellingcat, Scripps, BBC Verify) has geolocated the gunmen or linked them to Hamas. | ABC re‑host of IDF videociteturn7view0 |
| **Pattern of fire at aid queues** | The U.N. human‑rights office says *“over 410* Palestinians have been killed **by Israeli fire** while trying to reach GHF sites since late May” and calls the model the “weaponisation of food.”citeturn18view0  It has **not** attributed any fatal shootings to Hamas. |
| **Aid‑worker casualties blamed on Hamas** | Only the 11 June GHF bus ambush is on record. Reuters could not obtain independent confirmation; Hamas declined comment.citeturn10view0 |
| **Aid looting / interference** | A confidential U.N. memo and a U.S. official say organised *crime gangs*, **not Hamas**, are the main looters of aid convoys near Kerem Shalom; some gangs operate “under passive or active protection” of the IDF.citeturn17view0 |
| **UN & NGO eyewitness databases** | The OHCHR, WHO, MSF and the Palestine Red Crescent consistently list Israeli troops, GHF security contractors and unidentified armed gangs—not Hamas—as the shooters at aid lines. (No incidents naming Hamas appear in their public sit‑reps up to 24 July 2025.) |

---

## 3 | How plausible is Hamas involvement?

* **Motive:** Hamas has an interest in **undermining GHF**, which it sees as an Israeli‑imposed alternative to UNRWA and a lever of forced displacement.  
* **Capability:** The group retains scattered armed units in Khan Younis and around Rafah despite battlefield losses.  
* **Opportunity:** GHF sites are in Israeli‑controlled corridors with drones overhead; militants would risk rapid detection.  
* **Cost‑benefit:** Killing hungry civilians—Hamas’s own support base—would be a politically self‑defeating tactic unless the target were rival clans or collaborators (as in the contested bus attack).

Overall, the scenario is **possible but poorly evidenced** so far.  The stronger, repeatedly corroborated pattern is that most shooting around food lines comes from Israeli positions or private security hired by GHF.

---

## 4 | Key claims fact‑checked

| Claim | Verdict | Reason |
|-------|---------|--------|
| **“Hamas routinely shoots at aid seekers.”** | **Unsubstantiated.** Only one video supplied by the IDF shows unidentified gunmen; no independent body has verified their affiliation. No UN or NGO database lists Hamas as a shooter at aid sites.citeturn7view0turn18view0 |
| **“The 11 June ambush proves Hamas targets food workers.”** | **Inconclusive.** GHF blames Hamas; Reuters notes lack of corroboration and clan feud motives.citeturn10view0 |
| **“Hamas steals or blocks most aid.”** | **Contradicted by UN memo and U.S. officials**, who report no physical interference by Hamas and point instead to organised gangs operating in IDF‑controlled zones.citeturn17view0 |

---

## 5 | Outstanding gaps & what would settle them

1. **Forensic imagery review** – independent geolocation, muzzle‑flash analysis and chain‑of‑custody checks on the 1 June drone footage.  
2. **Ballistic/medical forensics** – calibre matching of recovered rounds at aid sites.  
3. **Witness protection protocols** – secure interviews with survivors outside Gaza to reduce intimidation and propaganda bias.  
4. **Full incident logs** – release of IDF and GHF rules‑of‑engagement files and CCTV.

Until such material is public, the balance of evidence indicates that **Israel and GHF security—not Hamas—are responsible for the vast majority of deadly fire at food distribution points**, with only isolated, unverified allegations against Hamas.

parts: Research into the political bias on the United Nations, UNRWA, and major Western media news outlets since the Oct 7, 2023 attacks. Where bias exists, examine the direction of the bias, underlying motives, and the resultant impact of that bias. Determine the overall degree of caution warranted when consuming information from both Western mass media as well as official channels such as UN communications or government communications.

To tailor this research effectively, could you clarify the following:

1. Are you interested in all Western media or specific outlets (e.g., CNN, BBC, NYT, Fox News, etc.)?
2. Should the analysis focus only on coverage related to Israel-Palestine, or also broader geopolitical issues since Oct 7, 2023?
3. Would you like the research to include academic and NGO evaluations of bias (e.g., media studies, watchdog reports)?
4. Are you also looking for examples of accurate/unbiased coverage for contrast?

Once I have these details, I’ll launch a comprehensive and critical investigation into the biases of UN entities and Western media since Oct 7, 2023.
For Western media, focus on major and popular news outlets. Coverage Israel-Palestine and closely related geopolitical issues. Identifying accurate and unbiased coverage is also essential.

Understood. I will investigate political bias in United Nations communications, UNRWA, and major Western media outlets since the Oct 7, 2023 Hamas attacks. This will include analysis of the direction of bias, possible motives, and the effects on public perception. I’ll also identify credible and relatively unbiased sources for contrast, and assess the level of caution warranted when interpreting media or official narratives.

I’ll update you when the research is ready.

parts:
# Political Bias in the UN, UNRWA, and Western Media Since October 7, 2023

**Introduction:** The Hamas attacks on Israel on October 7, 2023, and the ensuing Israel–Gaza war set off intense scrutiny of how institutions and media portray the conflict. Allegations of political bias have been leveled at the United Nations (including its agencies like UNRWA) and at major Western news outlets. This research examines where such bias exists, the direction and motives behind it, and its impact on public understanding. We also assess how cautious readers should be when consuming information from Western mass media versus official sources (e.g. UN or government communications). The goal is to highlight patterns of bias in post–Oct 7 coverage of the Israel–Palestine conflict and encourage a critical approach to all sources of information.

## The United Nations: Accusations of Bias in the Israel–Palestine Conflict

The United Nations has faced *politicized perceptions* of bias from multiple sides. In the wake of Oct 7, Israeli officials accused the UN – and particularly Secretary-General António Guterres – of an **anti-Israel slant**. Guterres sparked controversy by stating that “the attacks by Hamas did not happen in a vacuum” while also condemning those attacks【2†L201-L209】. Israel’s ambassador blasted this as *justifying terror*, calling it part of the UN’s “continued bias and hatred of Israel,” and even demanded Guterres’ resignation【2†L210-L218】. This episode fed into Israel’s long-held belief that UN bodies disproportionately single it out – a view underpinned by the **many critical resolutions** and investigations Israel faces at the UN Human Rights Council and General Assembly【2†L225-L231】. Israeli retaliation included banning UN officials’ entry (to, in their words, “teach them a lesson”)【2†L219-L227】, reflecting severely strained relations. From Israel’s perspective, UN statements on Gaza (e.g. highlighting Palestinian suffering and urging ceasefires) exhibit a *pro-Palestinian bias*, whereas Hamas’s atrocities are not given equal weight. 

On the other hand, human rights advocates and many UN member states argue the opposite: that **structural power imbalances** in the UN favor Israel and impede justice for Palestinians. For example, the UN’s failure to halt what some term Israeli war crimes in Gaza has been attributed to the Security Council’s politics – chiefly the U.S. veto shielding Israel from binding action【10†L1-L4】. Critics note that while the UN often voices concern (Guterres called the Gaza crisis “a crisis of humanity”), it cannot enforce accountability due to great-power politics【9†L221-L229】【9†L231-L239】. This *bias by paralysis* means Israeli violations go unpunished at the international level, undermining Palestinian faith in the UN. Thus, perceptions of UN bias differ sharply: **pro-Israel voices see a UN biased against Israel**, while **pro-Palestinian voices see bias in the UN’s inability to constrain Israel**. Underlying these views are the UN’s unique constraints: its membership includes many developing countries sympathetic to the Palestinian cause, while a few Western powers align with Israel. Each side seizes on aspects of UN communications that favor their narrative – be it humanitarian concern for Gaza or denunciations of Hamas – and claims bias. 

*Impact:* The impact of this politicization is profound. Accusations of bias damage the UN’s credibility as a neutral peace-broker. Israel’s distrust has led to reduced cooperation – for example, revoking visas of UN humanitarian staff during the Gaza crisis【2†L171-L179】【2†L219-L227】 – which hinders aid delivery and diplomacy. Meanwhile, Palestinians and global civil society grow frustrated as UN warnings (about civilian suffering or possible war crimes) go unheeded. Overall, **consumers of UN communications should exercise caution**: UN reports on the conflict are grounded in international law and humanitarian data, but they are also subject to political pressures. It’s important to read *full context* (e.g. Security Council debates, UN fact-finding missions) rather than cherry-picked quotes, and to understand who is criticizing the UN and why. The UN remains a vital source of information (e.g. on humanitarian needs), but its statements often become battlegrounds for competing narratives – requiring readers to discern facts from politicized interpretations.

## UNRWA Under Fire: Allegations Against the UN’s Palestine Refugee Agency

【36†embed_image】 **UNRWA humanitarian operations in Gaza:** UNRWA, with over 13,000 staff, provides essential education, health, and food services to Palestinians in Gaza【16†L191-L199】. Since Oct 7, 2023, the agency has been thrust into political controversy over its neutrality. 

UNRWA (the U.N. Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees) faced an **unprecedented backlash** after the Hamas attacks. Israeli officials alleged that *some UNRWA employees were complicit* in the October 7 assault, claiming that Hamas had deeply infiltrated UNRWA’s ranks【16†L211-L219】【30†L75-L83】. In the following months, Israel moved to delegitimize the agency: in early 2024 its parliament even passed bills to ban UNRWA from operating in Israel and absurdly designated it a “terrorist organization”【16†L173-L182】. Several Western governments temporarily froze funding pending investigations【16†L215-L224】. **Underlying these accusations** is a long-held belief among Israeli officials and supporters that UNRWA is biased *in favor of Palestinians*, given that it employs many local Palestinians and focuses exclusively on Palestinian refugees. They point to past incidents (such as Hamas weapons being hidden in UNRWA schools or allegations of antisemitic content in UNRWA-run textbooks) as evidence that the agency is not truly neutral. Israel’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs claimed new intelligence “exposed the involvement” of UNRWA staff in terror and accused UNRWA’s leadership of *whitewashing* the problem as just “a few rotten apples,” rather than rooting out a systemic issue【30†L75-L83】. The **direction of this perceived bias** is clear: from Israel’s vantage, UNRWA is *too sympathetic to Palestinians*, potentially even harboring terrorists – a stance that serves to discredit any UNRWA reports critical of Israeli actions.

UNRWA and the UN reject these broad accusations. After extensive internal inquiries, the U.N. fired *nine* UNRWA employees on suspicion of involvement in the Oct 7 attacks【16†L230-L238】 – indicating that a handful of staff may indeed have violated the agency’s neutrality. However, no evidence emerged of any official UNRWA policy complicity. UNRWA’s leadership emphasizes that **misinformation and disinformation** about its work have *“intensified since the war in Gaza began”*【16†L243-L251】, arguing that its staff have been unfairly smeared *“as terrorists, without a shred of evidence”*. All major donor countries eventually **reinstated funding** after these investigations, signaling that governments found no proof of institutional collusion with Hamas【16†L225-L233】. Underlying UNRWA’s perspective is its humanitarian mandate – it serves 2+ million Palestinian refugees, and many of its Palestinian staff have themselves been victims of the war. The *motive for bias* on UNRWA’s part, if any, would simply be to advocate for the civilians it serves. Indeed, UNRWA officials have been vocal about the *“sense of double standards”* in global reactions – wondering if the world would tolerate Gaza’s level of destruction were it happening to another population【16†L204-L213】【16†L206-L214】. Such statements, while humanitarian in nature, are viewed by Israel as political attacks. 

*Impact:* The feud over UNRWA’s neutrality has serious consequences. Israel’s moves to block UNRWA operations and label it terrorist were widely condemned as illegal, given UNRWA’s crucial role in feeding and sheltering Palestinians in war zones【16†L173-L181】【16†L254-L262】. Nonetheless, the climate of suspicion forced UNRWA to operate under extreme pressure – at one point its staff feared wearing U.N. logos, after airstrikes killed several UNRWA workers【16†L275-L284】. Over 260 UNRWA staff were killed in Gaza in the first year of the war【16†L283-L290】, a tragic toll that UNRWA says the U.N. could not prevent. The public impact is also notable: those inclined to distrust the U.N. now dismiss UNRWA reports (for example, on civilian casualties or famine risk) as biased or manipulated. Conversely, Palestinians and human rights groups see UNRWA as a lifeline and view attacks on it as attempts to *silence truthful reporting* of Gaza’s humanitarian crisis. In practical terms, **readers should approach UNRWA-related information with an understanding of this context**. UNRWA’s statistics and appeals (e.g. on refugee needs or casualty figures) are generally backed by U.N. verification – indeed, even Israeli intelligence eventually found Gaza’s health data **“generally accurate” despite earlier public claims to the contrary【18†L100-L108】【18†L150-L158】**. However, official Israeli or partisan sources may vigorously dispute UNRWA’s statements. Thus, one should cross-check critical facts (for instance, by consulting neutral observers like the International Red Cross or multiple news agencies) and be wary of unproven allegations aimed at undermining UNRWA.

## Western Media Coverage: Narratives, Biases, and Self-Correction

【37†embed_image】 **Western media outlets under scrutiny:** The BBC headquarters in London. Even within the BBC, journalists have accused their employer of double standards in covering Israeli vs. Palestinian suffering【31†L77-L85】. Major Western news organizations faced similar critiques of bias after Oct 7, 2023.

In the aftermath of October 7, **major Western news outlets** — from American networks like CNN and Fox News, to European broadcasters like the BBC — were accused of biased coverage of the Israel–Hamas war. Media analysts and Arab journalists observed a pervasive **pro-Israel slant** in mainstream Western reporting【4†L79-L87】. In practice, this bias took several forms: **asymmetrical empathy**, one-sided context, and loaded language. For instance, in many outlets the *grief and horror faced by Israeli victims* (after Hamas’s brutal attack that killed ~1,200 people) was exhaustively told through personal stories, interviews, and the repeated framing of Hamas as “terrorists” committing a “massacre.” Meanwhile, coverage of *Palestinian victims in Gaza* (who would ultimately number in the tens of thousands) initially reduced them to statistics or anonymous masses, often prefaced by Israeli and U.S. talking points about Hamas using civilians as “human shields”【4†L135-L142】. Media monitoring studies found that U.S. newspapers like *The New York Times* and *Washington Post* mentioned Israeli deaths far more often than vastly higher Palestinian casualties【5†L52-L60】. Emotional terms like “slaughter” or “atrocity” were almost exclusively used for Israeli victim narratives, whereas Palestinian deaths (even children’s) were reported with passive or sanitizing wording (e.g. “Palestinians *died*” rather than “were killed”)【5†L52-L60】. This **double standard in language** was so pronounced that it prompted comparisons to post-9/11 Islamophobic tropes – painting Muslims/Arabs as inherently violent or less human【4†L153-L161】. Western correspondents physically remained in Israel (since Gaza was sealed off to foreign press), meaning they “lived the Israeli narrative” day-to-day【4†L107-L115】【4†L119-L127】. The result, as one Gaza analyst put it, was that Palestinian suffering was not equally *humanized*: “You don’t hear the word ‘victims’ [for Palestinians] as you do for Israelis”【4†L133-L141】. Only much later, as grisly images of Gaza’s destruction grew impossible to ignore, did some Western outlets ramp up human-interest stories about Palestinians – but by then critics argued it was “too little, too late”【31†L169-L177】.

**Underlying motives** for this pro-Israel bias are multifaceted. One factor is alignment with Western government policies: in October 2023, the US, UK, and EU states vocally backed Israel’s right to respond, and media often reflexively echoed their framing of events. Internal communications at MSNBC (a liberal U.S. network) revealed that, *“amid America’s wave of sympathy for Israeli terror victims,”* the channel’s tone shifted to intense solidarity with Israel【35†L145-L154】【35†L181-L189】. In fact, MSNBC quietly benched three prominent Muslim-American anchors (including Mehdi Hasan and Ayman Mohyeldin) who were known for reporting critically on Israel, replacing them with other hosts during the peak of the war coverage【35†L145-L154】【35†L181-L189】. This suggested a **fear of appearing “too sympathetic” to Palestinians**, lest the network face backlash in a pro-Israel public climate. A similar dynamic played out in the UK: the BBC was pressured by politicians (including the Prime Minister and a future Foreign Secretary) to label Hamas explicitly as “terrorists,” breaking with its editorial guideline of using such terms only in attribution【33†L199-L208】【33†L239-L247】. While the BBC resisted outright, its reporters certainly did not shy from emphasizing Hamas’s brutality. At the same time, BBC insiders felt the broadcaster went out of its way to **avoid showing Palestinian humanity**, likely to preempt claims of bias. In a leaked 2,300-word letter, *BBC journalists accused their own organization* of *“investing greater effort in humanising Israeli victims”* than Palestinian ones【31†L77-L85】. They pointed out that the BBC’s coverage of Ukraine showed no such hesitation to condemn an aggressor, yet in Gaza the BBC was *“failing to help the public understand the human rights abuses unfolding”* by Israel【31†L118-L126】. The letter cited as motive that the BBC seemed overly deferential to UK/US government positions, noting the timing of improved Gaza coverage only when Western officials’ “appetite” for Israel’s bombardment began to wane【31†L169-L177】.

Notably, **not all perceived bias leaned pro-Israel** – there were also high-profile instances of media seemingly favoring the Palestinian narrative, which drew criticism and subsequent correction. The most glaring example was the reporting on the Al-Ahli Hospital explosion on Oct 17, 2023. In the immediate aftermath, outlets including *The New York Times* ran prominent headlines attributing *Palestinian officials’ claims* that an Israeli airstrike killed hundreds at the hospital. These reports were published quickly, **“relying too heavily on claims by Hamas, and [not making] clear that those claims could not immediately be verified,”** as the *NY Times* later admitted in a rare editors’ note【28†L359-L367】. Within a day, evidence emerged suggesting the blast was likely caused by a misfired Palestinian rocket, not an Israeli bomb. The initial reports (which turned out to be misleading) were seized upon by pro-Israel commentators as proof of anti-Israel bias in Western media. An Israel Defense Forces spokesperson lambasted international outlets for being *“so fast and trigger-happy to report what Hamas was saying”* without skepticism【28†L426-L434】【28†L428-L436】. Fox News and other conservative media shamed competitors for “parroting Hamas talking points”【28†L392-L400】. This episode underscores that **bias can also result from journalistic error or uncritical amplification of one side’s claims**, especially under breaking-news pressure. The *motive* here may not have been ideological bias so much as the rush for information in a fog-of-war scenario – yet the effect was a narrative harmful to Israel (and a blow to the outlets’ credibility).

*Impact:* The overall impact of Western media biases has been two-fold. First, it **skewed public perception**, especially in the crucial early weeks of the war. In Western countries, many citizens initially received a largely one-dimensional story – one in which Israeli victims’ stories dominated and Palestinian suffering was downplayed or contextualized as unfortunate but inevitable. This likely bolstered public support for Israel’s military campaign by muting moral outrage over Gaza’s civilians. As one media expert noted, such coverage *“legitimises Israeli violations of international law”* by omitting the historical and legal context of Palestinian trauma【4†L79-L87】【4†L83-L91】. On the other side of the world, audiences in the Middle East and Global South saw this imbalance as evidence that Western media cannot be trusted on Palestine at all. Arab viewers in particular found the “mainstream” Western agencies’ credibility *“irreparably damaged”*【4†L79-L87】 – turning instead to alternative outlets (like Al Jazeera) or social media to hear Palestinian accounts. This global divide in trust is dangerous, fueling suspicions that media are simply extensions of government propaganda or cultural bias. The second major impact has been **internal turmoil within news organizations**. The war prompted extraordinary pushback from journalists themselves: more than 750 Western journalists (including from top outlets) signed an open letter in November 2023 **criticizing their own industry’s coverage as dehumanizing and overly deferential to Israel**【8†L33-L41】. They urged newsrooms to use accurate legal terms like “apartheid” or “ethnic cleansing” where applicable, noting it’s a double standard that media routinely note Hamas is designated a terrorist group but won’t note that major human rights groups label Israel an apartheid regime【8†L69-L77】【8†L79-L87】. Such unprecedented dissent led to difficult debates in newsroom leadership about impartiality versus truth-telling. A few journalists who spoke out faced repercussions – for example, a *NY Times* contributor resigned after management pressured her over signing a pro-Palestine letter【8†L129-L137】. All of this indicates that consumers should apply **serious caution and media literacy skills** when following Western media on this conflict. Even reputable outlets might omit key facts or context due to bias, and occasionally they may report unverified claims (as seen with the hospital blast) – so readers must triangulate information from multiple sources and be aware of a given outlet’s slant.

## Finding Accurate and Unbiased Coverage

With biases on all sides, **identifying accurate and balanced information** about the Israel–Palestine conflict requires active effort. No single source is without bias, but one can get nearer to the truth by comparing diverse sources. For straight facts, international wire services like **Reuters and the Associated Press** are a good starting point – they have longstanding reputations for rigorous fact-checking and relatively neutral wording. (However, even they operate within constraints; for example, they often rely on official figures for casualties and may use cautious language like “Israel says…”, which still needs context.) In fact, the AP went so far as to **analyze the Gaza Health Ministry’s death toll data** to test its reliability, finding patterns (e.g. the proportion of women and children killed) that lent credibility to the figures【18†L135-L144】【18†L140-L148】. Such efforts at transparency can help readers trust that data is not being wildly fabricated. It’s also wise to **consult respected humanitarian organizations**: U.N. agencies (like OCHA or WHO), the International Committee of the Red Cross, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, etc., regularly release reports on civilian impact, often with methodologies explained. (Their terminology – e.g. describing certain Israeli actions as potential “war crimes” – is based on international law, not propaganda, and can counterbalance more euphemistic media coverage.) That said, as noted, even U.N. reports are accused of bias by one side or the other, so check if multiple independent bodies corroborate a claim.

Another strategy is to **read across the spectrum** of media. Compare a major U.S. outlet’s framing with that of a Middle Eastern outlet like *Al Jazeera* or a European public broadcaster. For example, where a U.S. network might lead with Israeli security concerns, Al Jazeera might lead with Palestinian civilian stories – the truth often lies in acknowledging *both*. Within Western media, note the **language cues**: is a militant attack described with moral outrage while a bombing of civilians is in passive voice? If so, the outlet might have an unconscious bias – seek out another report on the same event from a source with a different editorial stance to fill in what’s missing. Increasingly, voices from the Global South or independent journalists on the ground (including freelancers in Gaza or Israel) share firsthand accounts on social media. These can humanize the conflict, though they also require verification. Always consider the source’s background and incentive: Are they embedded with one side’s military? Are they known activists? Use that to weight their credibility, but don’t dismiss them outright. 

Crucially, be aware of **government communications** and their influence. During this war, official narratives were often amplified by media: Israeli government spokespeople and the U.S. State Department held frequent briefings, while Hamas and the Gaza authorities put out their own statements. All such **official communications have agendas** – whether it’s Israel downplaying civilian harm, Hamas exaggerating civilian death tolls for sympathy, or Western governments emphasizing support for Israel while quietly urging restraint. As an example, when Gaza’s Health Ministry announced a high death toll, President Biden publicly said he had “no confidence” in those numbers【18†L153-L160】 – a statement likely aimed at preserving political support for Israel. Yet behind closed doors, **even Israeli intelligence accepted those same casualty figures as credible**【18†L100-L108】. This teaches an important lesson: what officials say is not always the factual truth, but often a political positioning. Therefore, treat **all official claims with healthy skepticism**. Look for independent confirmation (satellite images, multiple eyewitnesses, third-party assessments) before believing extraordinary statements about battlefield events. If a government or army denies something that numerous credible journalists or observers report, consider why they might lie or what they gain by obfuscating.

## Navigating Bias: How Careful Should We Be?

In light of the above, a high degree of caution is warranted for consumers of both Western mass media and official communications. **Western media**, despite generally upholding professional standards, clearly exhibited *narrative bias* in this conflict – so one should never rely on a single outlet or take emotive coverage at face value. Always ask: *What am I not hearing?* If a report focuses solely on one side’s suffering or justification, seek out information on the other side from another source. It is telling that journalists themselves have called out their industry for failing to fully inform the public【31†L118-L126】【8†L33-L41】. Thus, readers must often fill the gaps by reading beyond the headlines and beyond the mainstream. Meanwhile, **official channels** (whether UN statements or national government pronouncements) should be approached as pieces of a puzzle rather than the whole picture. The UN’s humanitarian updates are valuable, but remember they may omit political context or pull punches due to diplomatic pressure. Government briefings are even more suspect – they serve national interests first. For example, Israeli officials in this war sought to control the narrative tightly (at times even refusing or revoking press access to critical voices), and Hamas’s information is obviously propagandistic and unverifiable on many points. In practice, **treat war communications as you would advertising**: persuasive and possibly informative, but not impartial truth. 

The degree of caution needed is therefore **very high** for both media and official info, albeit for different reasons. With media, bias may come from editorial choices or cultural lens rather than an intent to deceive, but it can still mislead – so cross-check stories and be aware of omission bias. With official sources, assume a motive and look for what facts may be selectively presented or hidden. One effective approach is to **verify sensational claims** (e.g. a massacre, use of forbidden weapons, etc.) through fact-checking organizations or open-source intelligence communities, which often investigate viral war claims. During the Gaza war, for instance, independent analysts scrutinized videos and satellite imagery of key incidents (like the hospital blast) to piece together what likely happened, providing a corrective to conflicting narratives. 

In conclusion, consuming information about the Israel–Palestine conflict (especially post-Oct 7, 2023) demands critical thinking and a nuanced approach. Bias has been evident in UN arenas, humanitarian agencies have been politicized, and Western news outlets – while not monolithic – have shown clear leanings and blind spots. **The overall lesson for readers is caution, not cynicism**: one should neither gullibly accept the first version of a story nor despair that *all* information is propaganda. By comparing multiple reputable sources, recognizing each one’s potential bias, and paying attention to fact-based reporting (even if it challenges one’s preconceived narrative), it is possible to approach the truth. In a media landscape this polarized, an informed reader must *“hold power to account,”* as the journalists’ open letter implored【8†L63-L66】 – which includes holding the media and official institutions accountable by demanding accuracy, humanity, and context in their coverage. The Israel–Gaza war has underscored that doing so is essential to truly understand events beyond the bias. 

**Sources:** The analysis above is based on reporting from a range of connected sources, including statements by UN officials and member states, internal critiques from journalists, media watchdog reports, and investigative articles on the Gaza war’s coverage and impact【2†L201-L209】【2†L225-L231】【16†L211-L219】【16†L243-L251】【31†L77-L85】【31†L118-L126】【28†L359-L367】【18†L100-L108】, among others. These sources provide evidence of perceived biases and their consequences in the period since October 7, 2023. Each cited excerpt supports specific points regarding bias direction, motives, or impact as discussed. Users are encouraged to review these references for a deeper dive into how narratives were constructed and contested during this conflict.

metadata.title: The failures of the UN in the Israel-Palestine conflict | OpenGlobalRights
metadata.text: What the UN secretary-general has called “a crisis of humanity” is also a legal crisis. The current war and its history reflect a failure of the UN system to prevent and punish war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide. However, the responsibility for preventing the gravest of crimes falls not only on the UN but the entire international community, from individual states to civil society—and it is the latter that must prosecute and punish such crimes when the UN fails to do so.

metadata.title: The failures of the UN in the Israel-Palestine conflict | OpenGlobalRights
metadata.text: The Geneva Conventions of 1949 on international humanitarian law—the universal rules on warfare—prohibit punitive sieges and collective punishment, hostage-taking, torture, cruel and inhuman treatment, targeting civilians and civilian infrastructure, and the forcible displacement of civilian populations. They require all parties to ensure that civilians have food, water, and essentials to survive during a conflict and guarantee that they can safely leave conflict areas and return home. Violations of these prohibitions and obligations are war crimes and can also be crimes against humanity or genocide, depending on their gravity and the perpetrators’ intent.

content_references.title: The failures of the UN in the Israel-Palestine conflict | OpenGlobalRights
content_references.snippet: What the UN secretary-general has called “a crisis of humanity” is also a legal crisis. The current war and its history reflect a failure of the UN system to prevent and punish war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide. However, the responsibility for preventing the gravest of crimes falls not only on the UN but the entire international community, from individual states to civil society—and it is the latter that must prosecute and punish such crimes when the UN fails to do so.

content_references.title: The failures of the UN in the Israel-Palestine conflict | OpenGlobalRights
content_references.snippet: The Geneva Conventions of 1949 on international humanitarian law—the universal rules on warfare—prohibit punitive sieges and collective punishment, hostage-taking, torture, cruel and inhuman treatment, targeting civilians and civilian infrastructure, and the forcible displacement of civilian populations. They require all parties to ensure that civilians have food, water, and essentials to survive during a conflict and guarantee that they can safely leave conflict areas and return home. Violations of these prohibitions and obligations are war crimes and can also be crimes against humanity or genocide, depending on their gravity and the perpetrators’ intent.

metadata.async_task_title: Bias in UN and Western Media on Israel-Palestine Since Oct 7, 2023

parts:
In light of the findings relating to bias in western media reporting, UN channels and other official government channels, devise an action plan for the Singapore Government to:

- Strengthen our education curriculum, including implementing urgent measures, to innoculate our students against propaganda, promote critical thinking with respect to highly sensitive issues relating race and religion and the Israel-Palestine conflict in particular, encourgae an attitude of objectivity, discernment, and discretion, and develop a deep sense awareness of one's own bias and attitudes.

- Implement a broad set of policy measures to address the risk of polarization of SIngapore society as a result of this conflict and the potential for the citizenry to consume biased sources, including official government and UN communications, and strongly promote an attitude of balance, circumspection, and respect for the sensitivity of the issues at hand.

- Actively engage the broader citizenry and religious communties in particular, especially Muslim, Christian, and Judaism communities in Singapore, to strengthen inter-faith dialog, promote a healthy discussion of sensitive issues, and strengthen resiliance and mutual respect for each other.

**Crafting the plan**

The user is developing an action plan to address bias in media and promote critical thinking. This involves creating an educational curriculum, revising it for bias awareness, engaging religious communities, and monitoring societal polarization.

**Concluding sources**

Piecing together various sources, including the CCE syllabus, IMDA report, and Harmony Circle info. Mentioning POFMA's extensive use and a new council.

**Researching key terms**

I’m gathering insights on "cyber wellness" and "critical thinking" from a PDF to aid with referencing. Progressing through sections to explore online safety insights.

**Assessing PDF constraints**

Evaluating file access due to remote limitations, considering smaller lineno or opening again.

**Mapping out strategies**

Let's see how IRCC 2024 measures strengthen interfaith and racial harmony. This is an exciting prospect!

**Analyzing Harmony Circle**

I'm considering describing Harmony Circle's current activities based on the policies and the description only updated in May 2025.

**Crafting a comprehensive policy**

I'm thinking through an educational and civic plan to address social issues. Focusing on media literacy, digital resilience, and interfaith engagement, all while considering implementation timelines and evaluation metrics.

**Gathering citations**

I’m gathering citations from the CCE syllabus for critical thinking, the Online Safety Code for social media guidelines, Harmony Circle aims, and the ST POFMA article. Progress is steady.

**Navigating options**

I'm piecing together strategies to bypass blocked access to Straits Times. Exploring different domain possibilities like Channel News Asia for potential POFMA-related content.

**Initiating the search**  
I'm starting a comprehensive search across various domains to gather all necessary information.

**Strategizing the response**

Integrating education, policy, and engagement, leveraging Harmony Circles and POFMA.

**Action Plan: Safeguarding Social Cohesion and Critical Literacy in Singapore amid the Israel‑Palestine Information War** --- ## 1 Strategic Goals 1. **Inoculate students and citizens against propaganda** by embedding advanced media‑ and information‑literacy (MIL) skills in schools and public life. 2. **Prevent polarisation on race‑ and religion‑sensitive issues**—especially those flowing from the Israel‑Palestine conflict—through proactive policies and calibrated communication. 3. **Deepen inter‑faith trust and resilience** by empowering religious communities to engage in fact‑based, empathetic dialogue. All measures align with the Constitution, the Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act (MRHA, amended 2019) and Singapore’s multi‑racial compact. citeturn0search4 --- ## 2 Curriculum & Pedagogy Reforms (MOE lead) | Horizon | Measure | Details | KPIs | |---------|---------|---------|------| | **Immediate (AY 2026 intake)** | **Fast‑track a “Critical Digital Literacy” unit** into Lower‑Secondary Humanities. | • Insert a compulsory 10‑hour module using live case‑studies on Israel‑Gaza coverage (how headlines, imagery, statistics and official claims can be framed).
• Leverage existing inquiry‑based Social Studies syllabus that already covers source analysis. citeturn0search2 | 100 % Sec 1 cohort complete module; pre/post quiz shows ≥30 % rise in misinformation‑detection scores. | | | **Teacher crash‑course on propaganda analysis.** | • 2‑day in‑service training (NIE + Media Literacy Council).
• Adapt best‑practice toolkits from Finland’s anti‑disinformation curriculum. citeturn0search6 | 2 000 teachers trained within 6 months; 85 % rate course “useful/very useful”. | | **1‑3 yrs** | **Embed UNESCO Media & Information Literacy (MIL) competencies** across English, Mother‑Tongue, Art and CCE. | • Map UNESCO MIL framework to Singapore syllabi. citeturn0search1turn0search7
• Introduce graded assessment of bias detection and ethical information sharing. | MIL components in ≥4 subjects by 2028; students score ≥70 % on new national MIL benchmark. | | | **Capstone “Global Perspectives & Bias” elective for upper secondary & JC.** | Deep‑dive seminar comparing coverage of Ukraine vs. Gaza, U.N. vs. state propaganda, data‑verification labs, and reflections on personal bias. | 25 % uptake by first cohort; participant survey shows higher empathy and analytical rigour. | | **3‑5 yrs** | **AI‑assisted personalised MIL practice platform** (GovTech + IMDA). | Adaptive quizzes on deepfakes, logical fallacies, rhetorical bias; dashboard for teachers/parents. | Platform reaches 80 % of students by 2030; average critical‑thinking score improves 10 % year‑on‑year. | *Governance:* MOE to convene a **Curriculum Rapid‑Response Panel** (educators, psychologists, media scholars, religious representatives) to update content within six months when global flashpoints arise. --- ## 3 Whole‑of‑Government Polarisation‑Risk Policies (MCI/MHA lead) ### 3.1 Precision Public Communication * **Balanced language protocol.** Ministries must publish conflict‑related statements with: (i) explicit source citations, (ii) contextual timelines, (iii) acknowledgement of uncertainty, and (iv) links to multi‑lateral law (ICRC, UN resolutions). * **“Heat‑map of sensitivities”.** ISD and REACH to maintain a real‑time dashboard on online sentiment (in four languages). Trigger thresholds prompt rapid myth‑busting explainers via Gov.sg and official Telegram/WhatsApp channels. * **Open‑data fact‑checks.** Expand Factually.sg to publish the raw datasets behind official claims so that researchers can replicate analysis. ### 3.2 Digital & Media‑Literacy Push * **National MIL Campaign 2026.** Mass‑media outreach (TV, TikTok micro‑learning clips) illustrating bias traps; independent ombuds panels for content disputes. | | Religious actors feel co‑opted | Maintain co‑creation approach; fund community‑initiated programmes through equal‑access grants. | | Curriculum overload for teachers | Provide plug‑and‑play lesson kits, AI marking aids, and time‑tabling flexibility. | | Digital natives bypass formal channels | Gamify MIL content and partner with micro‑influencers on emerging platforms. | --- ### Conclusion This multi‑layered action plan leverages Singapore’s existing strengths—strong schools, trusted institutions, and vibrant inter‑faith networks—while filling critical gaps exposed by the global information war over Gaza. items.title: Online influencers need 'urgent' fact-checking training, warns Unesco
items.snippet: Unesco has issued a warning emphasizing the urgent need for fact-checking training among social media influencers to mitigate the spread of misinformation. According to a survey by Unesco, two-thirds of content creators do not verify the accuracy of their information before sharing, leaving both themselves and their followers susceptible to incorrect information. The report highlights the necessity for media literacy education to improve public discourse and trust in media. Findings showed that personal experience, informal research, and popularity of sources were often prioritized over official sources. Unesco has collaborated with the Knight Center for Journalism in the Americas to provide an online course aimed at enhancing influencers' fact-checking and content creation skills. While many creators have a limited understanding of journalistic practices and relevant regulations, only half of those surveyed clearly disclosed sponsorships. The survey sampled 500 creators from various regions, mainly under 35, with up to 10,000 followers on platforms such as Instagram and Facebook.
